ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:0.6_0: Venerables, these rules to be trained in come up for recitation.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.2_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore their sarongs hanging down in front and behind.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.3_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind? They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.5_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.6_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.7_0: “How can the monks from the group of six wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.8_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.9_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks from the group of six:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.10_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.13_0: “... Foolish men, how can you do this?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.14_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.15_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.16.1_0: ‘“I will wear my sarong evenly all around,” this is how you should train.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.17_0: One should wear one’s sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.18_0: If a monk, out of disrespect, wears his sarong hanging down in front or behind, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.19.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.21_0: To give rise to the robe.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.26_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.27_0: The first training rule is finished.
